newsitem.title: FINLAND: Neste buys 10 pct of Vattenfall gas unit.
newsitem.headline: Neste buys 10 pct of Vattenfall gas unit.

text.p: Finnish oil and energy group Neste Oy said in a statement on Wednesday it had bought 10 percent of Swedish energy group Vattenfall AB's natural gas unit, Vattenfall Naturgas AB.

Neste said Vattenfall had sold 49 percent of the natural gas unit. The other buyers were Germany's Ruhrgas AG (14.5 percent), Danish firm Dansk Olje og Naturgas A/S (10 percent) and Norway's Statoil AS (14.5 percent).

Vattenfall Naturgas is expected to sell nearly 900 million cubic metres of natural gas this year, up from slightly more than 850 million cubic metres in 1996, Neste said, adding the company's turnover was over 800 million Swedish crowns in 1995. It did not give the natural gas sales volume for that year.

Vattenfall Naturgas brings natural gas through a pipeline it owns to Gothenburg in southwest Sweden from Dragor in Denmark. It sells the gas through various distributors to some 55,000 end-users in southwest Sweden.
About 50 percent of the gas is used for district heating, 35 percent is used by industry and 15 percent by services.

For Vattenfall, the aim of the sale of half of its natural gas unit was "to develop the natural gas market in Sweden further and to increase the share of natural gas in the Swedish energy system", Vattenfall CEO Carl-Erik Nyquist said in Neste's statement.

Executive vice president Tapio Harra at Neste's energy division said Neste saw "an opportunity to exploit Sweden's growing natural gas market and to promote the realisation of the Nordic Gas Grid and a common Nordic natural gas market".
"The most powerful north European power companies have now joined forces," Harra said.
The Nordic Gas Grid is on the list of the European Union's Trans-European Energy Network (TEN). The first feasibility study of the grid will be co-financed by the European Commission.
Neste was responsible for coordinating the feasibility study, it said.
